metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Analyse the use of a magnetic field to change the path of a charged particle, including: the magnitude and direction of the force applied to an electron beam by a magnetic field: F = qvB, in cases where the directions of v and B are perpendicular or parallel; the radius of the path followed by an electron in a magnetic field: qvB = mv²/r, where v << c

magnetic_force_formula.name: Magnetic Force Formula
magnetic_force_formula.correct: The magnetic force on a moving charge is F = qvB, where q is the charge, v is the speed, and B is the magnetic field strength.

F = qB.error: Missing velocity. No motion = no magnetic force.
F = qB.fix: Magnetic force requires motion. F = qvB includes speed v.
F = qB.action: Check: a stationary charge in a magnetic field feels zero force.

F = vB.error: Missing charge. The force depends on how much charge is moving.
F = vB.fix: F = qvB. Both charge q and velocity v matter.
F = vB.action: Units check: (C)(m/s)(T) = N. What happens without C?

F = qv/B.error: Wrong operation. It's multiplication, not division.
F = qv/B.fix: F = qvB means q times v times B.
F = qv/B.action: Stronger field should give more force, not less.

F = qE.error: That's electric force, not magnetic force.
F = qE.fix: Electric: F = qE. Magnetic: F = qvB. Different fields, different formulas.
F = qE.action: Magnetic force needs velocity. Electric force doesn't.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the magnetic force formula correctly.
persistent.action: Write F = qvB ten times. Then calculate force for three different scenarios.

perpendicular_condition.name: Perpendicular Condition for Maximum Force
perpendicular_condition.correct: Magnetic force is maximum when velocity is perpendicular to the magnetic field. When parallel, the force is zero.

maximum when parallel.fix: When v is parallel to B, there's no magnetic force. Must be perpendicular.
maximum when parallel.action: Think: a charge moving along field lines feels no deflecting force.

same regardless of angle.fix: Force depends on sin(θ). At 90° (perpendicular), sin = 1. At 0° (parallel), sin = 0.
same regardless of angle.action: Calculate F at 90° and 0°. Very different results.

maximum when at 45 degrees.fix: Maximum force needs sin(θ) = 1, which occurs at 90°.
maximum when at 45 degrees.action: Plot sin(θ). Maximum is at 90°, not 45°.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how angle affects magnetic force.
persistent.action: The full formula is F = qvB sin(θ). Calculate F for θ = 0°, 30°, 60°, 90°.

parallel_zero_force.name: Zero Force When Parallel
parallel_zero_force.correct: When a charge moves parallel to a magnetic field, the magnetic force is zero. No deflection occurs.

maximum force.error: Opposite. Parallel gives zero, not maximum.
maximum force.fix: A charge moving along field lines isn't deflected at all.
maximum force.action: Parallel means the charge is moving WITH the field direction. No sideways push.

half the maximum force.action: A charge can travel along B forever with no magnetic force.

force along the field direction.error: Magnetic force is always perpendicular to both v and B.
force along the field direction.fix: The force can never be along B. It must be perpendicular.
force along the field direction.action: Use right-hand rule. Force is always sideways to motion.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the perpendicular nature of magnetic force.
persistent.action: Key rule: magnetic force is always perpendicular to velocity. Parallel motion = no perpendicular component.

right_hand_rule.name: Right-Hand Palm Rule
right_hand_rule.formula: Fingers → B, Thumb → v, Palm → F (for positive charges)
right_hand_rule.correct: Point fingers in B direction, thumb in v direction, palm pushes in force direction. For negative charges, reverse the force direction.

palm points in field direction.error: Wrong assignment. Fingers point in field direction.
palm points in field direction.fix: Fingers → B, Thumb → v, Palm → F.
palm points in field direction.action: Practice: fingers along B, thumb along v, palm shows force.

thumb points in field direction.error: Thumb is for velocity, not field.
thumb points in field direction.action: Memory aid: 'v' for velocity, 'v' looks like thumb.

same direction for positive and negative.error: Negative charges feel force in opposite direction.
same direction for positive and negative.fix: Right-hand rule gives force on positive charges. Reverse for electrons.
same direction for positive and negative.action: For electrons: find force using right-hand rule, then flip direction.

persistent.gap: You're not applying the right-hand rule correctly.
persistent.action: Practice 10 problems. Always identify v and B first, then apply rule. Remember to reverse for electrons.

electron_force_reversal.name: Force Direction for Negative Charges
electron_force_reversal.formula: Electron force is opposite to right-hand rule result
electron_force_reversal.correct: Electrons (negative charges) experience force in the opposite direction to what the right-hand rule predicts for positive charges.

same direction as positive charges.error: Negative charge means opposite force direction.
same direction as positive charges.fix: Use right-hand rule to find force on positive charge, then reverse for electron.
same direction as positive charges.action: In same field, electron and proton are deflected in opposite directions.

no force on electrons.fix: Electrons are charges. Moving charges feel F = qvB. The force is just reversed.
no force on electrons.action: Electron beams are bent by magnets. This proves they feel force.

depends on the field strength.error: Direction depends on charge sign, not field strength.
depends on the field strength.fix: Positive charge → right-hand rule direction. Negative → opposite direction. Always.
depends on the field strength.action: Field strength affects magnitude, not direction.

persistent.gap: You're forgetting that electrons are negative charges.
persistent.action: Always add this step: 'Is the charge positive or negative?' If negative, reverse the force direction.

circular_motion_condition.name: Circular Motion in Magnetic Fields
circular_motion_condition.correct: A charged particle moving perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field follows a circular path because the magnetic force is constant in magnitude and always perpendicular to velocity.

moves in a straight line.error: The force deflects the particle continuously.
moves in a straight line.fix: Constant perpendicular force causes circular motion, not straight line.
moves in a straight line.action: Magnetic force keeps bending the path. Straight line needs zero force.

moves in a spiral.error: Spiral requires a component of velocity parallel to B.
moves in a spiral.fix: Pure perpendicular motion gives a circle. Spiral needs both parallel and perpendicular components.
moves in a spiral.action: If v is exactly perpendicular to B, the path is a perfect circle.

accelerates in a straight line.error: Magnetic force is perpendicular to motion, so it changes direction, not speed.
accelerates in a straight line.fix: Magnetic force does no work (perpendicular to motion). Speed stays constant.
accelerates in a straight line.action: Centripetal acceleration changes direction, not speed.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why perpendicular force creates circular motion.
persistent.action: Review circular motion: constant magnitude force perpendicular to velocity = circular path.

radius_formula.name: Radius of Circular Path
radius_formula.correct: The radius of circular motion is r = mv/(qB). Larger mass or speed increases radius. Larger charge or field decreases radius.

r = qB/(mv).error: Inverted fraction. Mass and velocity go on top.
r = qB/(mv).fix: r = mv/(qB). Momentum (mv) in numerator, qB in denominator.
r = qB/(mv).action: Check: faster particle should have larger radius. Does your formula give that?

r = mv/B.fix: r = mv/(qB). Charge matters because magnetic force depends on charge.
r = mv/B.action: Units: (kg)(m/s)/[(C)(T)] = m. You need C in denominator.

r = qvB/m.fix: Start from qvB = mv²/r and solve for r. Get r = mv/(qB).
r = qvB/m.action: Derive it: qvB = mv²/r → r = mv²/(qvB) → r = mv/(qB).

r = mv²/(qB).fix: One v cancels when deriving. Result is r = mv/(qB), not mv²/(qB).
r = mv²/(qB).action: From qvB = mv²/r: divide both sides by qvB, get r/v = m/(qB), so r = mv/(qB).

persistent.gap: You need to practice deriving the radius formula.
persistent.action: Start from qvB = mv²/r. Solve for r step by step. Verify: r = mv/(qB).

mass_effect_on_radius.name: Mass Effect on Radius
mass_effect_on_radius.correct: Radius is directly proportional to mass. A heavier particle traces a larger circle in the same field.

inversely proportional to mass.error: Opposite. More mass means larger radius.
inversely proportional to mass.fix: r = mv/(qB). Mass m is in the numerator. More mass = bigger r.
inversely proportional to mass.action: Heavier particle is harder to deflect. Think of turning a truck vs a car.

independent of mass.fix: r = mv/(qB) shows m directly affects r.
independent of mass.action: Compare proton and electron at same speed: proton has ~2000× larger radius.

proportional to mass squared.fix: r = mv/(qB). Mass appears to the first power, not squared.
proportional to mass squared.action: Double the mass = double the radius. Not quadruple.

persistent.gap: You're not reading proportionality from formulas correctly.
persistent.action: In r = mv/(qB), identify what's in numerator vs denominator. Numerator variables are directly proportional.

speed_effect_on_radius.name: Speed Effect on Radius
speed_effect_on_radius.correct: Radius is directly proportional to speed. A faster particle traces a larger circle.

inversely proportional to speed.fix: r = mv/(qB). Speed v is in the numerator. More speed = bigger r.
inversely proportional to speed.action: Faster particle is harder to bend. Like a car turning—higher speed needs wider turn.

independent of speed.fix: r = mv/(qB) shows v directly affects r.
independent of speed.action: Double the speed = double the radius.

proportional to speed squared.fix: One v cancels in derivation. r ∝ v, not v².
proportional to speed squared.action: Double speed = double radius. Not quadruple.

persistent.gap: You're confusing radius formula with kinetic energy (which has v²).
persistent.action: Compare: KE = ½mv² (v squared) vs r = mv/(qB) (v to first power).

field_effect_on_radius.name: Magnetic Field Effect on Radius
field_effect_on_radius.correct: Radius is inversely proportional to magnetic field strength. A stronger field bends the particle more, giving a smaller radius.

directly proportional to field.fix: r = mv/(qB). B is in the denominator. More B = smaller r.
directly proportional to field.action: Stronger magnet bends the path more tightly.

independent of field.fix: r = mv/(qB). B directly affects r (inversely).
independent of field.action: Double the field = half the radius.

proportional to field squared.error: B appears to first power in denominator.
proportional to field squared.action: Double B = half r. Not quarter r.

persistent.gap: You're not reading inverse relationships from formulas.
persistent.action: When variable is in denominator, relationship is inverse. Practice: if B doubles, r = ?

speed_unchanged.name: Speed is Unchanged by Magnetic Force
speed_unchanged.correct: Magnetic force is always perpendicular to velocity, so it does no work and cannot change the particle's speed—only its direction.

speed increases.error: Magnetic force cannot do work (perpendicular to motion).
speed increases.fix: Work = Fd cos(θ). When θ = 90°, cos(90°) = 0, so W = 0.
speed increases.action: Perpendicular force changes direction, not speed.

speed decreases.error: Magnetic force cannot slow the particle.
speed decreases.fix: No work done means no change in kinetic energy. KE = ½mv² stays constant.
speed decreases.action: The particle circles at constant speed. Like a planet orbiting.

speed oscillates.fix: Magnetic force only redirects motion. Speed is unchanged throughout the circle.
speed oscillates.action: Check any point on the circular path—same speed everywhere.

persistent.gap: You don't understand that perpendicular forces do no work.
persistent.action: Review work formula: W = Fd cos(θ). When force is perpendicular to displacement, W = 0.

centripetal_force_source.name: Magnetic Force as Centripetal Force
centripetal_force_source.correct: The magnetic force provides the centripetal force needed for circular motion. Setting F_magnetic = F_centripetal gives qvB = mv²/r.

separate forces act.error: There's only one force—the magnetic force IS the centripetal force.
separate forces act.fix: Centripetal force isn't a new force. It's just what we call any force causing circular motion.
separate forces act.action: The magnetic force equals the required centripetal force. They're the same thing.

friction provides centripetal force.error: No friction in magnetic deflection of particles.
friction provides centripetal force.fix: In a vacuum, only the magnetic force acts on the charged particle.
friction provides centripetal force.action: Electron beams work in vacuum. Only magnetic force is present.

gravity provides centripetal force.error: Gravity is negligible for fast-moving electrons.
gravity provides centripetal force.fix: For charged particles in magnetic fields, magnetic force dominates completely.
gravity provides centripetal force.action: Compare: magnetic force on electron is ~10¹² times stronger than gravitational.

persistent.gap: You're treating centripetal force as a separate force.
persistent.action: Centripetal = 'center-seeking'. It's a role, not a type. Here, magnetic force plays that role.
